(102) 
tedious to be read at the Societies Meetings;
I there-
fore desire the following Extract
may be acceptable. 
<u>M<sup>r<\sup> Consett<\u> <s>notes<\s>, from the beginning noteth down 
the Barometrical Variations, but I know not his Di-
visions, & Degrees, 'till Decemb.18, at 3<sup>h<\sup>. p.m, 
and then the Barometer was at 30.66 Wind N E<sup>1<\sup>. 
and Fair. 
From Novemb. 24 to the End of the Month, the 
Weather was Cloudy, with Snow, and a deep Snow 
on the last Day, & Fair on the 28th. The Winds 
were Easterly & NE, of 2 and 3 Degrees
Strength, 
'till the 29th and 30th, and then S E<sup>3</sup>. S<sup>4</sup>. and S W<sup>3</sup>.
In Decemb. it was Cloudy, with some Snow, 'till 
Dec. 8 and 9, which were Fair days. Th<s>c<\s>en Cloudy 
on the 10th and 11th, and Rain in the Evening. Af-
terwards some cloudy & moist Air; some Fair, 'till 
Dec 23, and then Hail; Wind S W<sup>3</sup> The next 
Day Snow; and the rest of the Month some Cloudy 
and Dark, with Snow, and some Fair. The
Barome-
ter ever since the 18th, hath been above 30 Inches, 
and on Dec.26 it was 30.84; on Dec. 30, 30.96, 
and 31.00; and lastly on Dec. 31, it was 31.12, 
<s>which is the highest Range of the Quick-silver in all 
the Observations, and if I mistake not, the highest I 
ever met with any where, and at any time. 
And now having mentioned the highest 
Range, I 
shall take Notice of the lowest, 
which was on Jan.
21, at 28.36, Wind W<sup>4<\sup>. and Snow.<s>
In Jan.1724/5. on y<sup>e<\sup> 3<sup>th<\sup> day  y<sup>e<\sup> Barometer was 30.65. on y<sup>e<\sup> 
4<sup>th<\sup>. before noon 31.32, after noon 31.35. but on y<sup>e<\sup> 5<sup>th<\sup> it was in y<sup>e<\sup> 
afternoon <s>it was<\s> 31.59. the Wind SW<sup>1<\sup>. & cloudy weather  <u>wch<\u> is y<sup>e<\sup> highest Range of the 
Quicksilver in all y<sup>e<\sup> Observations, & if I mistake not, y<sup>e<\sup> 
highest I ever met with any where & at any time. On y<sup>e<\sup> other hand the lowest 
Range was on Feb. 25. at 28.28. Wind W<sup>4<\sup>. & snow. 
In Jan. 1724. the Barometer was above 30 In-
ches all the beginning of <s>the Month<\s> <u>Jan.<\u>, 'till the 18th, 
and then it gradually fell to 28.36, <s>as I said<\s>. The 
Winds, for the most part, were in some Westerly Point 
'till Jan. 11, and then S E<sup>2<\sup>. with Fair, and an hard 
Frost
